PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.

Name: J. Payne
Address: Glenworth, Sask.
Birthplace: Ponca, Nebraska, U.S.A., 1876

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1910
Where did you set up housekeeping? Sec. 4 - Tp. 5 - Rg. 6 - M. 3rd
Where had you been living before that? Lawrence Co., Neb., U.S.A.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 10
How far was it to your nearest store? 6-7 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? At anytime
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years?
Canned milk, oatmeal, flour, sugar, cornflakes and others

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Robin Hood
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs. at times
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Can't remember
How much did you use graham flour?
Whole wheat flour?
Was flour milled locally? No
How far away? How far away? What year? Can't remember
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Can't remember
What other grain products did you use? Oatmeal
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Farina? Atime
Other? Can't remember
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
How did you grind it?
